com.projetloki.genesis

Class Selector

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.projetloki.genesis.Selector

  • public abstract class Selector
extends Object
    A CSS selector, to match a set of elements in an HTML or XML documents. There are several matching criteria, such as the tag name, the id, the class name, the position in the tree, the presence of a pointing device on top of the element. Elements matched by a selector are called the subjects of the selector.

    There are two ways to construct a selector. The first way is to specify the CSS notation of the selector with the from factory method. The second way is to filter the elements matched by the universal selector with methods such as onTag and onId.

    The two selectors below are equal: 

     Selector s1 = Selector.from("div.foo a");
 Selector s2 = ANY.onTag("div").onClass("foo").asAncestor().onTag("a");
 assertEquals(s1, s2);

    Selectors are immutable.

    Note: Although this class is not final, it cannot be subclassed as it has no public or protected constructors.

    Author:
    Cl√©ment Roux
    See Also:
    MDN

    • Field Detail

      • ANY

        public static final Selector ANY
        The universal selector, matching any element.

    • Method Detail

      • from

        public static Selector from(String selectorString)
        Returns a selector instance that has the given CSS notation. The CSS notation of a selector is the string that is used to represent the selector in a CSS file.

        Usage example: 

         Selector s1 = Selector.from("div.foo a");
 Selector s2 = ANY.onTag("div").onClass("foo").asAncestor().onTag("a");
 assertEquals(s1, s2);

        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given string is not the CSS notation of a selector

      • asAncestor

        public final Selector asAncestor()
        Returns a selector that matches the descendants of this selector's subjects. The CSS notation is
        ancestor *
        with a space separating the ancestor and the universal selector.
        See Also:
        MDN

      • asAncestorOf

        public final Selector asAncestorOf(String descendant)
        Returns a selector that matches the descendants of this selector's subjects matched by the given selector. The CSS notation is
        ancestor descendant
        with a space separating the ancestor and the descendant.

        This is same as passing the result of Selector.from(descendant) to asAncestorOf(Selector).

        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given string is not the CSS notation of a selector
        See Also:
        MDN

      • asAncestorOf

        public abstract Selector asAncestorOf(Selector descendant)
        Returns a selector that matches the descendants of this selector's subjects matched by the given selector. The CSS notation is
        ancestor descendant
        with a space separating the ancestor and the descendant.
        See Also:
        MDN

      • asParent

        public final Selector asParent()
        Returns a selector that matches the children of this selector's subjects. It does NOT match the grand-children nor other descendants of this selector. The CSS notation is
        parent > *
        See Also:
        MDN

      • asParentOf

        public final Selector asParentOf(String child)
        Returns a selector that matches the children of this selector's subjects matched by the given selector. It does NOT match the grand-children nor other descendants of this selector. The CSS notation is
        parent > child

        This is same as passing the result of Selector.from(child) to asParentOf(Selector).

        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given string is not the CSS notation of a selector
        See Also:
        MDN

      • asParentOf

        public abstract Selector asParentOf(Selector child)
        Returns a selector that matches the children of this selector's subjects matched by the given selector. It does NOT match the grand-children nor other descendants of this selector. The CSS notation is
        parent > child
        See Also:
        MDN

      • asSibling

        public final Selector asSibling()
        Returns a selector that matches the siblings of this selector's subjects. The CSS notation is
        sibling - *
        See Also:
        MDN

      • asSiblingOf

        public final Selector asSiblingOf(String sibling)
        Returns a selector that matches the siblings of this selector's subjects matched by the given selector. The CSS notation is
        sibling - selector

        This is same as passing the result of Selector.from(sibling) to asSiblingOf(Selector).

        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given string is not the CSS notation of a selector
        See Also:
        MDN

      • asSiblingOf

        public abstract Selector asSiblingOf(Selector sibling)
        Returns a selector that matches the siblings of this selector's subjects matched by the given selector. The CSS notation is
        sibling - selector
        See Also:
        MDN

      • asPrecedingSibling

        public final Selector asPrecedingSibling()
        Returns a selector that matches the adjacent siblings of this selector's subjects. The CSS notation is
        sibling + *
        See Also:
        MDN

      • asPrecedingSiblingOf

        public final Selector asPrecedingSiblingOf(String adjacentSibling)
        Returns a selector that matches the adjacent siblings of this selector's subjects matched by the given selector. The CSS notation is
        sibling + selector

        This is same as passing the result of Selector.from(nextSibling) to asPrecedingSiblingOf(Selector).

        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given string is not the CSS notation of a selector
        See Also:
        MDN

      • asPrecedingSiblingOf

        public abstract Selector asPrecedingSiblingOf(Selector adjacentSibling)
        Returns a selector that matches the adjacent siblings of this selector's subjects matched by the given selector. The CSS notation is
        sibling + selector
        See Also:
        MDN

      • onTag

        public abstract Selector onTag(String tagName)
        Returns a selector matching elements matched this selector and with the given tag name. For example, the selector ANY.onClass("foo").onTag("p") matches all paragraphs with the class name "foo", and is equivalent to ANY.onTag("p").onClass("foo").

        Another word for tag name is element type.

        Since elements can't have more than one tag name, it is not legal to call this method on a selector already matching elements by tag name. For instance,

        ANY.onTag("div").onTag("p")
        is illegal and throws a runtime exception, but the code below is legal because the two element type selectors apply to different sets of elements
        ANY.onTag("div").asAncestor().onTag("p")

        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given tag name is not a valid identifier
        IllegalStateException - if this selector already matches elements by tag name
        See Also:
        MDN

      • onClass

        public abstract Selector onClass(String className)
        Returns a selector matching elements matched by this selector and with the given class name. The class HTML attribute assigns a whitespace-separated list of class names to an element.

        Class selectors can be combined. For example ANY.onClass("foo").onClass("bar") matches all elements with both class names "foo" and "bar".

        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given class name is not a valid identifier
        See Also:
        MDN

      • onId

        public abstract Selector onId(String id)
        Returns a selector matching elements matched by this selector and with the given ID. Since ID attributes must have unique values, an ID selector can never match more than one element in a document.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given ID is not a valid identifier
        See Also:
        MDN

      • on

        public abstract Selector on(AttributePredicate attributePredicate)
        Returns a selector matching elements matched by this selector and that satisfy the given attribute predicate.
        See Also:
        MDN

      • on

        public abstract Selector on(PseudoClass pseudoClass)
        Returns a selector matching elements matched by this selector and if the given pseudo-class applies.
        See Also:
        MDN

      • on

        public abstract Selector on(PseudoElement pseudoElement)
        Returns a selector matching virtual elements within the elements matched by this selector.

        Pseudo-elements may only be appended after the last simple selector of the selector. It is forbidden to derive the selector returned by this method, or an IllegalStateException is thrown.

        See Also:
        MDN

        public String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
